Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Distributed coherence: fundamental building blocks, system concepts, and experimental demonstration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past two decades, advances in multi-antenna wireless systems have opened up the possibility of tremendous increases in wireless communication throughputs. The practical realization of these increases in real-world wireless networks is constrained by size and cost considerations that limit the number of antennas, especially for mobile devices. This research aims to achieve the gains from multi-antenna techniques in a distributed fashion by having groups of wireless transceivers pool together and cooperatively act like a virtual antenna array. The concept of virtual arrays has broad transformative potential for wireless networks by extending the numerous benefits of multi-antenna systems to networks of single-antenna devices. We will prototype and demonstrate virtual array techniques experimentally on a software-defined radio platform, and we plan to share our implementations as reusable building blocks to stimulate technology transition and to promote interactions between the academic, open-source software community and radio hobbyist communities. The elements of a virtual array have an unknown, typically time-varying, geometry and are driven by independent oscillators, each with stochastic drift; the main technical challenge is in maintaining distributed coherence in the array in the presence of these effects. While this is a very challenging problem, recent results have demonstrated the feasibility of virtual arrays.

This research will establish a solid theoretical foundation for distributed coherence and chart a clear path to technology transfer by applying the theory and techniques to the cross-layer design of concept systems based on virtual antenna arrays. Specifically we will develop a state space framework for tracking and prediction of oscillator dynamics and mobility, and scalable architectures for distributed transmission and reception appropriate for large distributed arrays of low-cost single-antenna devices. We will also identify fundamental tradeoffs and scaling laws for virtual arrays. We will apply and integrate the theory and techniques to two concept systems of great societal significance: Distributed base station provides multi-antenna capabilities even for low carrier frequencies where standard antenna arrays would be too bulky (e.g., white space frequencies). Distributed 911, enables a cluster of nodes to communicate with a possibly moving distant rescue vehicle which would be out of range for any one of the nodes. Our goal is to perform design and performance evaluation in sufficient detail to clear conceptual hurdles for implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MIMO communications involving centralized systems of multiple transmitters and receivers is revolutionizing modern communications, and has found its way into most modern standards. Yet it currently requires large centralized infrastructures that can be unwieldy. For example a cell phone cannot have large antenna systems. This project is concerned with Distributed MIMO (DMIMO) where groups of transmitters and receivers collaborate to form virtual antenna arrays to become virtually indistinguishable from large infrastructure heavy centralized antenna systems. Though conceived in the late seventies, and rigorously theoretically srudied by information theorists, until recently this idea has been dismissed by practitioners as being unworkable. This is so as each transceiver carries its own oscillator, and these quickly drift out of synchrony destroying the prospect of synchronous communication inb a matter of fractions of seconds. This project takes a comprehensive theoretical and practical view of DMIMO in an attempt to give practical substance.

 

We have shown that two key components of DMIMO, distributed beamforming, where transmitters collaborate to form a beam at a target, and distributed nullforming where they form nulls to protect targets from their transmission, can be realized through the following  techniques: First the use of novel Kalman Filtering techniques to maintain synchrony. Second the use of common feedback signals from target receivers, known as aggregate feedback, that guide transmitter actions.

 

We have provided strong theoretical results proving that our algorithms are scalable, robust and practically globally stable. We have provided a series oif experimental demonstrations that validate our theory on Software Defined Radios, that are notoriously difficult to manage. We have also shown how nullforming can be used for better localization. 

 

We have trained many graduate students, two women and one of African origin. Our partnership has also benefitted Raytheon-BBN, leading to potetial long term technology transfer.

Specific outcomes include the following.

1) Development of a nullforming algorithm where using an aggreagate feedback common to all transmitters from the receiver where the null is to be formed, transmitters only adjust their phases to achieve a null at a designated receiver, by using an iterative algorithm to minimize the power at the receiver. Though the received power is a nonconvex function of phases (such functions are very difficult to minimize) our algorithm is provably practically globally convergent. Further, even though nullforming is notoriously sensitive to channel estimation errors, simulations show that our algorithm achieves deep nulls despite very large estimation errors.

 

2) We have developed aniother algorithm where with receiver coooperation, transmitters simultaneously achieve a null at some receivers and beams at others. Unlike 1) here they are allowed to adjust both the gains and phases of their transmission. We have theoretically shown that the algorithm achieves vanishingly small errors in the face of noise and converges arbitrarily fast as the number of transmitters increases. A comprehensive theoretical analysis is provided.

 

3)  We have separately studied the achievable limits of communications capacity and transmission power in beamforming for DMIMO when there are multiple transmitters and a single receiver. We have exposed interesting structures to this problem that greatly simplify finding the solution, and have provided an algorithm for obtaining the solution.

4) As noted above, the decentralized structure of DMIMO requires synchronization of transmitters with different oscillators. We have developed a Kalman filtering framework that permits oscillator states to be efficiently tracked. In particular we show that for homogeneous oscillators an eighth order system can be used to obtain the theoretical performance, no matter how many transmitters there are. Secondly Kalman filter performance is very sensitive to assumed values of oscillator drift variance. We have developed a state of the art method for estimating these parameters that outperforms all its competitors.

5) We have provided a number of demonstrations of distributed  beam and nullforming using software defined radios that have notoriously poor oscillators. We note that prior to our work no demonstration of distributed nullforming had existed.

6) We have developed novel localization techniques that rely on nullforming at a target. The central premise of tis work is that a good null can only be formed at a target if its location is known to a high degree of precision. This has important application to the concept of D911 for rescuing and locating groups stranded due to natural or man made disasters.

In summary, this research has led to a comprehensive theoretical and practical study of DMIMO communications. We have provided performance limits, theoretical bounds and convergence properties. Through our software defined radio experiments we have validated our theoretical research and have shown that DMIMO is indeed feasible. It is our hope and belief that this research will give practical substance to DMIMO and revolutionize communications in areas with low infrastructure or where the infrastructure is severly impaired by natural or man made disasters. Among other things this may dent  the digital divide.
